title: Using interpolation with verbatim string literals

inline_content.Text: Using interpolation with verbatim string literals

title: Using
c

before the string will cause the string to be interpreted verbatim. So, e.g. Unicode characters or line breaks will stay exactly as they’ve been typed. However, this will not effect the expressions in an interpolated string as shown in the following example:Console.WriteLine($@“In case it wasn’t clear: \u00B9 The foo is {foo}, and the bar is {bar}.”); Output:

inline_content.Text: before the string will cause the string to be interpreted verbatim. So, e.g. Unicode characters or line breaks will stay exactly as they’ve been typed. However, this will not effect the expressions in an interpolated string as shown in the following example:Console.WriteLine($@“In case it wasn’t clear: \u00B9 The foo is {foo}, and the bar is {bar}.”); Output:

title: With string interpolation,
expressions
i
within curly braces
c
can also be evaluated. The result will be inserted at the corresponding location within the string. For example, to calculate the maximum of
foo
c
and
bar
c
and insert it, use
Math.Max
c
within the curly braces:Console.WriteLine($“And the greater one is: { Math.Max(foo, bar) }”);

inline_content.Text: can also be evaluated. The result will be inserted at the corresponding location within the string. For example, to calculate the maximum of
within the curly braces:Console.WriteLine($“And the greater one is: { Math.Max(foo, bar) }”);

title: Note: Any leading or trailing whitespace (including space, tab and CRLF/newline) between the curly brace and the expression is completely ignored and not included in the output
i

inline_content.Text: Note: Any leading or trailing whitespace (including space, tab and CRLF/newline) between the curly brace and the expression is completely ignored and not included in the output

title: As another example, variables can be formatted as a currency:Console.WriteLine($“Foo formatted as a currency to 4 decimal places: {foo:c4}”);

inline_content.Text: As another example, variables can be formatted as a currency:Console.WriteLine($“Foo formatted as a currency to 4 decimal places: {foo:c4}”);

title: Foo formatted as a currency to 4 decimal places: $34.0000

inline_content.Text: Foo formatted as a currency to 4 decimal places: $34.0000

title: Or they can be formatted as dates:Console.WriteLine($“Today is: {DateTime.Today:dddd, MMMM dd - yyyy}”);

inline_content.Text: Or they can be formatted as dates:Console.WriteLine($“Today is: {DateTime.Today:dddd, MMMM dd - yyyy}”);

title: Statements with a
Conditional (Ternary) Operator
a
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ty67wk28.aspx
can also be evaluated within the interpolation. However, these must be wrapped in parentheses, since the colon is otherwise used to indicate formatting as shown above:

inline_content.Text: can also be evaluated within the interpolation. However, these must be wrapped in parentheses, since the colon is otherwise used to indicate formatting as shown above:

title: Console.WriteLine($"{(foo > bar ? "Foo is larger than bar!" : "Bar is larger than foo!")}");

content_resolved.code: Console.WriteLine($"{(foo > bar ? "Foo is larger than bar!" : "Bar is larger than foo!")}");

title: Escaping backslash (
c
) and quote (
c
) characters works exactly the same in interpolated strings as in non-interpolated strings, for both verbatim and non-verbatim string literals:

inline_content.Text: ) characters works exactly the same in interpolated strings as in non-interpolated strings, for both verbatim and non-verbatim string literals:

title:
Console.WriteLine($"Foo is: {foo}. In a non-verbatim string, we need to escape \" and \\ with backslashes.");
Console.WriteLine($@"Foo is: {foo}. In a verbatim string, we need to escape "" with an extra quote, but we don't need to escape \");

Console.WriteLine($"Foo is: {foo}. In a non-verbatim string, we need to escape \" and \\ with backslashes.");

string interpolation expression
is not always
a

a simple string. The compiler decides which type to assign depending on the context:string s = $“hello, {name}”; System.FormattableString s = $“Hello, {name}”; System.IFormattable s = $“Hello, {name}”;

title: Call the above method with:AddLogItem($“The foo is {foo}, and the bar is {bar}.”); For example, one could choose not to incur the performance cost of formatting the string if the logging level was already going to filter out the log item.

title: There are implicit type conversions from an interpolated string:var s = $“Foo: {foo}”; System.IFormattable s = $“Foo: {foo}”; You can also produce an

c
variable that allows you to convert the string with invariant context:var s = $“Bar: {bar}”; System.FormattableString s = $“Bar: {bar}”;

inline_content.Text: There are implicit type conversions from an interpolated string:var s = $“Foo: {foo}”; System.IFormattable s = $“Foo: {foo}”; You can also produce an
variable that allows you to convert the string with invariant context:var s = $“Bar: {bar}”; System.FormattableString s = $“Bar: {bar}”;

title: It’s possible to use interpolated strings in Linq statements to increase readability further.

inline_content.Text: It’s possible to use interpolated strings in Linq statements to increase readability further.

title:
var fooBar = (from DataRow x in fooBarTable.Rows
          select string.Format("{0}{1}", x["foo"], x["bar"])).ToList();

content_resolved.code:
var fooBar = (from DataRow x in fooBarTable.Rows
          select string.Format("{0}{1}", x["foo"], x["bar"])).ToList();

title:
var fooBar = (from DataRow x in fooBarTable.Rows
          select $"{x["foo"]}{x["bar"]}").ToList();

content_resolved.code:
var fooBar = (from DataRow x in fooBarTable.Rows
          select $"{x["foo"]}{x["bar"]}").ToList();

title: Interpolated strings, however, will not compile with placeholders referring to non-existent variables. The following will not compile:

inline_content.Text: Interpolated strings, however, will not compile with placeholders referring to non-existent variables. The following will not compile:

title:
public const string ErrorFormat = $"Exception caught:\r\n{error}";
// CS0103: The name 'error' does not exist in the current context

content_resolved.code:

// CS0103: The name 'error' does not exist in the current context

title: If you’re localizing your application you may wonder if it is possible to use string interpolation along with localization. Indeed, it would be nice to have the possibility to store in resource files
String
c
s like:“My name is {name} {middlename} {surname}” instead of the much less readable:

inline_content.Text: If you’re localizing your application you may wonder if it is possible to use string interpolation along with localization. Indeed, it would be nice to have the possibility to store in resource files
s like:“My name is {name} {middlename} {surname}” instead of the much less readable:

content_resolved.code: "My name is {0} {1} {2}"

title: String
c
interpolation process occurs
at compile time
i
, unlike formatting string with
string.Format
c
which occurs
at runtime
i
. Expressions in an interpolated string must reference names in the current context and need to be stored in resource files. That means that if you want to use localization you have to do it like:

inline_content.Text: . Expressions in an interpolated string must reference names in the current context and need to be stored in resource files. That means that if you want to use localization you have to do it like:

title: If the resource strings for the languages used above are correctly stored in the individual resource files, you should get the following output:

inline_content.Text: If the resource strings for the languages used above are correctly stored in the individual resource files, you should get the following output:

title: Bonjour, mon nom est John Hallo, mein Name ist John Hello, my name is John

inline_content.Text: Bonjour, mon nom est John Hallo, mein Name ist John Hello, my name is John

title: Note
b

that this implies that the name follows the localized string in every language. If that is not the case, you need to add placeholders to the resource strings and modify the function above or you need to query the culture info in the function and provide a switch case statement containing the different cases. For more details about resource files, see
How to use localization in C#
a
https://stackoverflow.com/a/1142840/1016343

inline_content.Text: that this implies that the name follows the localized string in every language. If that is not the case, you need to add placeholders to the resource strings and modify the function above or you need to query the culture info in the function and provide a switch case statement containing the different cases. title: It is a good practice to use a default fallback language most people will understand, in case a translation is not available. I suggest to use English as default fallback language.

inline_content.Text: It is a good practice to use a default fallback language most people will understand, in case a translation is not available. I suggest to use English as default fallback language.
